image.altText: Fallen tree due to high winds, Tasmania.

props.synopsis: A "vigorous west to north-westerly airstream" is continuing to bring heavy rain and strong winds to Tasmania. Follow live.

title.children: Tasmania on flood alert as heavy rains batter state

image.altText: An elderly woman sits a cup of tea. Her face is not visible.

props.synopsis: Tasmania is the only Australian jurisdiction limiting the legal definition of family violence to abuse against a spouse or partner. Advocates say that approach creates barriers to accessing protective orders and support.

title.children: Jane has experienced abuse from her sons. In Tasmanian law, that's not family violence

image.altText: Protestors hold signs

props.synopsis: First came secret negotiations, then a site was chosen on the edge of a historic town. The townsfolk were enraged and the site was moved. More were enraged so it was moved again. Now a plan for a prison has officially been buried.

title.children: Site after site after site — how plans for a Tasmanian prison fell apart and left communities divided

image.altText: Two small wallabies share a kiss in the bushland.

props.synopsis: The traps have captured photographs of threatened species, unique animal behaviours — and even a currawong lifting a bin lid.

title.children: 'Something we've never seen before': Camera-trap photo competition spots wild neighbours

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair holding her 7 week old baby.

props.synopsis: Tasmanian mother Erin McGinn says there weren't enough midwives at the Royal Hobart Hospital to help her when she needed it after giving birth to her daughter, Amelia. Then later was forced to change to formula feeding.

title.children: 'I could have killed someone last night': Midwife says Royal Hobart Hospital maternity ward severely understaffed

image.altText: A man wearing a light blue liberal shirt stands at the front of a group of people who are all tossing their caps in the air.

props.synopsis: Premier Jeremy Rockliff has made unity a priority in a party plagued by discord, but this Saturday's state council meeting will tell how well that central tenet is being adhered to.

title.children: Just how united is the Tasmanian Liberal Party? We'll find out this weekend

image.altText: A high shot of Linda Reynolds in a media scrum answering questions outside the WA Supreme Court in Perth.

props.synopsis: It's unusual in Australia for MPs to resort to defamation proceedings, since parliamentary privilege allows them to speak freely in parliament without fear of legal action — but Senator Linda Reynolds felt it was the only way to repair her reputation.

title.children: Why the defamation battle between Linda Reynolds and Brittany Higgins may have unintended consequences

image.altText: Truck travels down regional road.

props.synopsis: A drunk driver jailed after a fatal crash in Queensland that killed a much-loved Tasmanian father of three has said he wished he had died in his place.

title.children: Drunk driver jailed for more than six years over crash that killed 'exceptional' Tasmanian father

image.altText: The entrance to the Royal Lodge at Windsor Park

props.synopsis: For years, King Charles and Prince Andrew have been at odds over a sweetheart deal cut between Andrew and his late mother to give him lifelong possession of a grand mansion on the grounds of Windsor Castle.

title.children: Charles reportedly wants to force his brother into Harry and Meghan's vacant house. Here's why

image.altText: A dark scene with a tower and a shadow

props.synopsis: Almost a million tourists come to Fiji every year. But behind the sun and sand, there's a dark side to the islands, with cartels using Fiji to import drugs into lucrative markets — a drug problem that has now spread into communities.

title.children: Cartels' trafficking of crystal meth through 'Pacific drug highway' sees addiction spread to Fiji's villages

image.altText: People swim at a beach next to the buildings of a nuclear plant.

props.synopsis: Canada's biggest province generates 51 per cent of its power from nuclear and while some love it, there are still downstream issues to be solved.

title.children: Big nuclear is on the Coalition agenda but Ontario, Canada shows there are still issues to resolve

image.altText: Houses under construction on a bright, sunny day

props.synopsis: The shadow assistant minister for home ownership says the Coalition would consider withdrawing GST payments to "hit the states hard where it hurts" and encourage housing supply.

title.children: Coalition would consider docking GST from states that don't build enough new homes

image.altText: A photo of Starbucks CEO Brian Niccol is surrounded by highlighted print documents

props.synopsis: The new Starbucks boss gets a jet for his commute — but that's just a sweetener.

title.children: It cost Starbucks $100m and a jet-fuelled commute to poach its new CEO

image.altText: Jaryd Clifford competing with his guide at the Paris Paralympics.

props.synopsis: Visually impaired athlete Jaryd Clifford is disqualified over a violation of guide rules, while Michael Roeger and Madison de Rozario win medals on the track at the Paris Paralympics.

title.children: 'A bit numb': Disqualified Clifford denied Paralympic bronze after rule breach

image.altText: Two coast guard ships collide.

props.synopsis: The Philippines and China exchange accusations of intentionally ramming coast guard vessels in disputed waters of the South China Sea, the latest in an escalating series of clashes in the vital waterway.

title.children: China, Philippines trade blame in latest South China Sea clash

image.altText: Kamala Harris speaking into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Vice-President Kamala Harris said in a statement on X that Donald Trump "disrespected sacred ground all for the sake of a political stunt," when he took photographs at Arlington National Cemetery.

title.children: Harris says Trump's appearance at Arlington National Cemetery 'disrespected sacred ground'

image.altText: Melissa Wu dives at the Glasgow Commonwealth Games

props.synopsis: Nationals leader David Littleproud said Victorians will be "embarrassed" as Glasgow underlines its bid for a streamlined 2026 Commonwealth Games, almost exclusively funded by $200 million of state government money.

title.children: Scottish Commonwealth Games bid 'adds to embarrassment' for Victorian government

image.altText: DJ Fatman Scoop smiles for camera

props.synopsis: Fatman Scoop, who topped charts in Europe with Be Faithful two decades ago and later contributed to hits by other artists, died after collapsing on stage at a show Friday in Connecticut, according to officials and his family.

title.children: Rapper Fatman Scoop dies at 53 after collapsing on stage in Connecticut

image.altText: A scenic view of rocks and mountains with the silhouette of a fighter jet flying low in the bright blue sky.

props.synopsis: Dramatic vision has emerged of an Australian F-35 jet performing risky, low-level tactical manoeuvres above the national park, in an incident believed to have raised eyebrows among senior air force figures.

title.children: Video shows jet performing daring flight manoeuvres, believed to have raised eyebrows among senior air force figures

image.altText: A photo showing a bearded Indigenious man wearing a black hat and looking directly at the camera

props.synopsis: Syphilis is continuing to spread through remote Indigenous communities in Central Australia, with shame and stigma keeping many from getting tested.

title.children: Sex can be a taboo topic — but as syphilis spreads, Bradley is having the tough conversations

image.altText: Alexei Popyrin holds up his hands

props.synopsis: Nick Kyrgios believes Alexei Popyrin has what it takes to win a grand slam title following his stunning victory over Novak Djokovic, but Popryin is trying to keep a lid on expectations.

title.children: 'Go get it, bro': Kyrgios tips Popyrin for grand slam success after US Open stunner

image.altText: frayed rope

props.synopsis: We need to be humble about what we don't know and policy needs to be evidence-based, Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy says.

title.children: Voters need to be heard, and we need to rebuild trust in expertise, warns Australia's Treasury secretary

image.altText: A graphic of a man and an air taxi

props.synopsis: Businessman John Wagner backs the use of flying taxis ahead of the 2032 Olympics but there are still a few hurdles for the technology to overcome.

title.children: Queensland multimillionaire joins 'air taxi' race ahead of 2032 Olympics

image.altText: A woman sits in a chair while her nails are filed at a salon in Melbourne.

props.synopsis: If you've been to a nail salon in Australia, chances are it was owned by a Vietnamese Australian. So, where did it all begin?

title.children: How Vietnamese Australians came to dominate the nail salon industry

image.altText: A video still of Tom Gleeson behind a podium. The ABC lissajous in the top left corner and the Hard Quiz logo in the top right

props.synopsis: Oh, you're back? Something to prove after last week's effort? Let's see what you've got.

title.children: Always said you'd smash Hard Quiz? I'll believe it when I see it

image.altText: On the left, the side of a man's head with a round, raised bump. On the left, a photo of the same face, but with the bump gone.

props.synopsis: A professor running a trial at Fiona Stanley Hospital says the science is moving towards personalised immunotherapy as a treatment for cancer.

title.children: Deadly lesion all but disappears in groundbreaking melanoma treatment trial

image.altText: A man and a woman sit looking in opposite directions appearing troubled.

props.synopsis: You might have got the impression from social media that attachment styles can predict your love life. This take on relationships twists science into "unhelpful nonsense," say psychologists.

title.children: 'Idiocy at its finest': How TikTok gets it wrong about relationship attachment styles

image.altText: A middle-aged woman readies a small dripper of liquid for a small child lying on a bed next to some pink balloons.

props.synopsis: Children began receiving vaccines on Saturday, Gaza's health ministry says, a day before the large-scale rollout and first three-day "humanitarian pause" in fighting agreed to by Israel and the UN's World Health Organization.

title.children: Children in Gaza begin receiving polio vaccine, while hostilities continue to worsen in occupied West Bank

image.altText: A man holding a painted stick in bushland

props.synopsis: Traditional owners share their knowledge to ward off the native animals after 16 high-risk dingo interactions this year.

title.children: K'gari visitors use Indigenous traditional method to protect themselves from dingoes

image.altText: Jake Gordon slides over to score a try

props.synopsis: The Wallabies have claimed a thrilling, one-point victory over Argentina in appalling conditions in La Plata.

title.children: Wallabies win thriller over Argentina with final kick of the game

image.altText: An Australian tennis player raises his hand in acknowledgement of the crowd after winning a match at the US Open.

props.synopsis: Alex de Minaur and Jordan Thompson join Alexei Popyrin in the US Open fourth round after setting up an all-Australian last-16 battle in New York.

title.children: Jordan Thompson, Alex de Minaur set up all-Australian clash in round of 16 at US Open

image.altText: Flower beds in full bloom.

props.synopsis: September's arrival signals the beginning of spring in Australia. But not everywhere follows the same system when it comes to changing seasons.

title.children: September 1 marks the beginning of spring in Australia. But how are the seasons measured elsewhere?

image.altText: A large shiny nugget of gold in an open palm

props.synopsis: Residents in a small Queensland town say gold fever is "deadset real" with the prospect of striking it rich drawing thousands of people in each year.

title.children: Tourists struck by gold fever as precious metal price soars

image.altText: two men, young and old, shaking hands in front of the ocean

props.synopsis: Kimberley youth Tremane Baxter-Edwards hopes to one day be Australia's first Indigenous prime minister.

title.children: The failed Voice referendum has 'galvanised' First Nations leaders in the Kimberley

image.altText: Casey Donovan dressed as a nun, in all black with a hint of white around her neck, a crucifix, hair out

props.synopsis: Casey Donovan stars as Deloris Van Cartier in Sister Act the musical, in a role made famous by Whoopi Goldberg in the 1992 film and 1993 sequel.

title.children: 'I hope I'm doing Deloris proud and also, Whoopi': Casey Donovan on her starring role in Sister Act the musical
